inlineContent.text: is an onscreen graphical element that can be initialized from an image or a solid color. SpriteKit adds functionality to its ability to display images using the functions discussed below.

abstract.text: Add high-performance 2D content with smooth animations to your app, or create a game with a high-level set of 2D game-based tools.
3D SceneKit content drawn as a flattened sprite.
The modes that describe how the source and destination pixel colors are used to calculate the new destination color.
A source of various particle effects.
A graphical element that draws text.
The base class of all SpriteKit nodes.
A mathematical shape that can be stroked or filled.
An image or solid color.
Defines the point in the sprite that corresponds to the node’s position.
The values of each attribute associated with the node’s attached shader.
The blend mode used to draw the sprite into the parent’s framebuffer.
Enable nine-part stretching of the sprite’s texture.
The sprite’s color.
A floating-point value that describes how the color is blended with the sprite’s texture.
A custom playground quick look for this instance.
Tells you when to initialize a sprite from an archive.
Initializes a single-color sprite node.
Initializes a textured sprite using an image file.
Initializes a textured sprite using an image file, optionally adding a normal map to simulate 3D lighting.
Initializes a textured sprite using an existing texture object.
Initializes a textured sprite in color using an existing texture object.
Initializes a textured sprite with a normal map to simulate 3D lighting.
Initializes a textured sprite using an existing texture object but with a specified size.
A mask that defines how this sprite is lit by light nodes in the scene.
A texture that specifies the normal map for the sprite.
Scales the sprite node to a specified size.
Sets an attribute value for an attached shader.
A text file that defines code that does custom per-pixel drawing or colorization.
A mask that defines which lights are occluded by this sprite.
A mask that defines which lights add shadows to the sprite.
The dimensions of the sprite, in points.
Initializes a single-color sprite.
Initializes a textured sprite using an image file.
Initializes a textured sprite using an existing texture object.
The texture used to draw the sprite.
Sets the value of a shader attribute.
A two-dimensional array of images.
A graphical element that plays video content.
A definition for a deformation of nodes that conform to
A protocol for objects that can be warped and animated by an
Play video in your scene by adding a video node.

abstract.text: Load a sequence of images and play them back at a rate you define, while optionally looping the resulting animation.

doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/.title: Animating a Sprite by Changing its Texture

abstract.text: Write custom GLSL code that modifies the look of your sprite.
Reinterpret a sprite’s alpha property to react differently to the objects below it.

doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/.title: Blending a Sprite with Different Interpretations of Alpha

abstract.text: Organize your app’s logic and display code with nodes.

doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/.title: Customizing the Behavior of a Node

abstract.text: Display visual content using SpriteKit.

doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/.title: Drawing SpriteKit Content in a View

abstract.text: Learn about the fundamental properties that provide a foundation for all other nodes.
Create a filled or stroked shape from a path object.
Learn the basics about using images, also known as sprites, with SpriteKit.
Add lighting and shadows to your scene with light nodes.

doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/.title: Lighting a Sprite with Light Nodes

abstract.text: Learn the basics about using textures in SpriteKit.
Structure your nodes for maximum performance.
Scale a sprite using nine-part algorithm.

doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/.title: Resizing a Sprite in Nine Parts

abstract.text: Provide a color and blend factor to additively color your sprite.
Learn how the anchor point affects a sprite’s position.

doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/.title: Using the Anchor Point to Move a Sprite

abstract.text: A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
